title: Can chaos exist without order? - Quora

response.answer_text: Right! We are told that the chaos addressed in chaos theory is not really THAT meaning of chaos. Yet it does seem to relate to *chaos*, chaos at least at times. It’s also not the same thing as disorder, yet chaos and disorder cross paths. One may wonder if order and disorder actually exist in an empirical sense, or are they merely a matter of perspective? One nifty concept in chaos theory is nonlinear order. There is a mountain range that lines the edge of my city. I look at each peak of the mountains and realize that they are recognizably similar yet obviously not identical. And that is an example of nonlinear order. You can compare blades of grass, clouds, people, fingerprints, and snow flakes. Same effect. Interestingly, “identical” coffee cups or brand new cars are each unique if very similar. In the cars think serial numbers, keys, locks and ignitions. They cannot occupy the same space at the same time. Think, too, of the molecular structure of each. Wear and tear will make each vehicle more distinct and recognizable for a coffee stain on the interior, windshield crack, or crumpled fender. Disorder creeps in and enhances their individuality, maybe? And that disorder is not necessarily about entropy in any direct sense although there is not much that does not include processes of entropy. Smash the windshield, which demonstrates the arrow of time and entropy, and that clearly seems like disorder. The arrow of time being a directional arrow for the one-way street of time. The smashed windshield will not spontaneously reform, which it might if time ran in reverse. If you grind wheat, that, too, demonstrates time’s arrow. Is THAT disorder? Or flour? It’s not about grinding the wheat deliberately to give the act purpose. The windshield can be smashed deliberately as well, (perhaps to save someone trapped inside.) and someone could accidentally throw a switch for the wheat grinder. As far as I grasp it the disorder in entropy is about energy dispersal, dissipation, and heat loss. Sometimes the heat loss is on a molecular level and not perceivable. Or it can be something like the explosion of a star, a necessary step in the formation of earth and life. While pondering all this at one point I wondered if an out of order bathroom is actually in a state of nonlinear order. Sorry I do not have a definitive answer.

Depends upon what you mean by “chaos”. If you mean “more entropy”, that is, more disorder, then no, more chaos comes from less chaos, and if you track it all the way back to BB, then the universe began in the highest state of order (the lowest entropic state) that it would ever be in, and the history of the universe is going from order to disorder, or to more chaos. If you mean “Chaos Theory”, then that’s a different question. Chaos is when tiny events have a disproportionate impact on the outcome of a series of events. That can result in a big mess (little c-chaos) or a higher form of order (Fractals, Complexity Theory).

In my mind, this is much the same question about darkness and light. I believe that darkness is the absence of light. However, I think that everything in the Universe has an elegant logic and order to it. Chaos is a kind of order we just don’t quite understand or comprehend without a certain effort of study and consideration. Perhaps relative to the way we express dim-light, or light radiating within a spectrum we don’t see. Perhaps my answer to this question is: In our Universe, there is no chaos, only varying types and levels of order.

Look up the term dichotomy to better help yourself understand what is going on.

Without any sort of order there is only randomness. So no, chaos cannot exist without order. Nor can anything else, apart from pure randomness. In mathematics, chaos is deterministic rules with positive feedback to small perturbations, that is, small perturbations grow. A single planet orbit around a sun is not chaotic because small perturbations don’t grow, it is stable, but three bodies orbiting each other *is* chaotic because small changes grow and change the shape of the orbit.

No, chaos is a biproduct of artificial order. It's something we notice because humans influence and manipulate, and rearrange every environment we touch to suit us. Prior to reorganizing nature on a massive level like we do in modern day, I'd imagine the chaos of the world before modern man was just right. No one knew any different to comment otherwise. Nature has its own natural order and patterns. We live to alter those patterns.

Chaos cannot generate order. “The fact is, however, that except in the very weak sense, Prigogine has not shown that dissipation of energy in an open system produces order. In the chaotic behavior of a system in which a very large energy dissipation is taking place, certain temporary structures (he calls them "dissipative structures") form and then soon decay. They have never been shown—even mathematically—to reproduce themselves or to generate still higher degrees of order.” Can Order Come Out of Chaos?

Is order necessary for chaos? Does order exist in chaos? No. Order does not need chaos. Chaos does not need order. One of them must exist without the other. Chaos cannot exist if there is complete order. Order cannot exist if there is complete chaos. If they exist together, then they exist independent from each other.
